thread.title: Found aircraft debris could be from missing MH370
thread.title_full: Found aircraft debris could be from missing MH370

title: Found aircraft debris could be from missing MH370
text:
Found aircraft debris could be from missing MH370 30 July 2015 Save 
Investigators are heading to Reunion Island to see if a washed-up part of Boeing 777 wing belongs to Malaysia Airlines’ missing MH370. 
Air safety investigators are already reported to have a “high degree of confidence” that the found piece, thought to be a flaperon which is a moving part of the wing unique to 777s, comes from the aircraft which disappeared in baffling circumstances in March 2014. 
Despite a lengthy and widespread search covering much of the Indian Ocean ever since, the find is the first to have given any real hope of solving the mystery. 
The team now heading to the French island to inspect the piece of wreckage will now focus on a number visible on it, comparing it with records to see if it comes from the missing aircraft. 
A total of 239 people were on board MH370 when it disappeared on a routine flight from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. 
The disappearance of the aircraft heralded a difficult year for the airline and came four months before another of its aircraft, MH17, was shot down over Ukraine in July by Russian-backed separatists with the loss of 298 lives. 
Following the disasters, Malaysia’s sovereign wealth fund Khazanah took total control of the company and has put in around $1.6 billion in an attempt to turn it around. 
The airline announced in March this year that it would cut its capacity by 10% with routes to the Middle East and Europe under “careful evaluation”. Up to 6,000 members of staff also face the sack as the airline prepares to undergo a restructure.
